question.title: Convert Existing Eclipse Project to Maven Project

node.contents: Does your existing build use an Ant script?

astNode.text: Does your existing build use an Ant script?

node.contents: You should probably switch accepted answer

astNode.text: You should probably switch accepted answer

node.contents: For a project at work, we're considering using the Maven plugin for Eclipse to automate our builds. Right now the procedure is far more complicated than it ought to be, and we're hoping that Maven will simplify things to a one-click build.

astNode.text: For a project at work, we're considering using the Maven plugin for Eclipse to automate our builds. Right now the procedure is far more complicated than it ought to be, and we're hoping that Maven will simplify things to a one-click build.

node.contents: My question is, is there a wizard or automatic importer for converting an existing Eclipse Java project to a Maven project, using the Maven plugin? Or should I create a new Maven project and manually copy over all source files, libs, etc.

astNode.text: My question is, is there a wizard or automatic importer for converting an existing Eclipse Java project to a Maven project, using the Maven plugin? Or should I create a new Maven project and manually copy over all source files, libs, etc.

node.contents: I was able to convert my project using chengdong's answer, but it didn't generate the directory structure that Maven suggests. I found that it wasn't difficult to create a new project and copy the source over.

astNode.text: I was able to convert my project using chengdong's answer, but it didn't generate the directory structure that Maven suggests. I found that it wasn't difficult to create a new project and copy the source over.

node.contents: I'm still new to Maven and I don't understand all the differences between these two approaches, but now I seem to have an actual Maven project as opposed to a Frankenstein that will install itself on my local repository.

astNode.text: I'm still new to Maven and I don't understand all the differences between these two approaches, but now I seem to have an actual Maven project as opposed to a Frankenstein that will install itself on my local repository.

node.contents: If my project was complete and I had no plans to change it, then the automatic converter probably would have been a fine solution for me.

astNode.text: If my project was complete and I had no plans to change it, then the automatic converter probably would have been a fine solution for me.

node.contents: It's necessary because, more or less, when we import a project from git, it's not a maven project, so the maven dependencies are not in the build path.

astNode.text: It's necessary because, more or less, when we import a project from git, it's not a maven project, so the maven dependencies are not in the build path.

node.contents: Here's what I have done to turn a general project to a maven project.

astNode.text: Here's what I have done to turn a general project to a maven project.

node.contents: general project-->java project right click the project, properties->project facets, click "java". This step will turn a general project into java project.

astNode.text: general project-->java project right click the project, properties->project facets, click "java". This step will turn a general project into java project.

node.contents: java project --> maven project right click project, configure-->convert to maven project At this moment, maven dependencies lib are still not in the build path. project properties, build path， add library, add maven dependencies lib

astNode.text: java project --> maven project right click project, configure-->convert to maven project At this moment, maven dependencies lib are still not in the build path. project properties, build path， add library, add maven dependencies lib

node.contents: And wait a few seconds, when the dependencies are loaded, the project is ready!

astNode.text: And wait a few seconds, when the dependencies are loaded, the project is ready!

node.contents: Interesting ! Is it ported to Luna ? Would the project still be an eclipse project (valid `.classpath` and `.project` files) ? Could you add to your answer how to use your plugin to mavenize a simple JavaSE project - and what would be the actual changes in directory structure ?

astNode.text: Interesting ! Is it ported to Luna ? Would the project still be an eclipse project (valid `.classpath` and `.project` files) ? Could you add to your answer how to use your plugin to mavenize a simple JavaSE project - and what would be the actual changes in directory structure ?

node.contents: Luna is the latest version of eclipse !!

astNode.text: Luna is the latest version of eclipse !!

node.contents: Sorry but I don't know what Luna is. It will not be valid eclipse project anymore as project directory structure gets changed. However creating modified eclipse configurations using Maven is easy. This is not a plugin but a tool. How to run it is mentioned already in README of project. The directory structure gets converted in Maven convention. So all sources go to src/main/java for instance.

astNode.text: Sorry but I don't know what Luna is. It will not be valid eclipse project anymore as project directory structure gets changed. However creating modified eclipse configurations using Maven is easy. This is not a plugin but a tool. How to run it is mentioned already in README of project. The directory structure gets converted in Maven convention. So all sources go to src/main/java for instance.

node.contents: I was having the same issue and wanted to Mavenise entire eclipse workspace containing around 60 Eclipse projects. Doing so manually required a lot of time and alternate options were not that viable. To solve the issue I finally created a project called eclipse-to-maven on github. As eclipse doesn't have all necessary information about the dependencies, it does the following:

astNode.text: I was having the same issue and wanted to Mavenise entire eclipse workspace containing around 60 Eclipse projects. Doing so manually required a lot of time and alternate options were not that viable. To solve the issue I finally created a project called eclipse-to-maven on github. As eclipse doesn't have all necessary information about the dependencies, it does the following:

node.contents:
• Based on <classpathentry/> XML elements in .classpath file, it creates the dependencies on another project, identifies the library jar file and based on its name (for instance jakarta-oro-2.0.8.jar) identifies its version. Currently artifactId and groupId are same as I couldn't find something which could return me the Maven groupId of the dependency based on artifactId. Though this is not a perfect solution it provides a good ground to speed up Mavenisation.

  • It moves all source folders according to Maven convention (like src/main/java)

  • As Eclipse projects having names with spaces are difficult to deal on Linux/Unix environment, it renames them as well with names without spaces.

  • Resultant pom.xml files contain the dependencies and basic pom structure. You have to add required Maven plugins manually.

astNode.text:
• Based on <classpathentry/> XML elements in .classpath file, it creates the dependencies on another project, identifies the library jar file and based on its name (for instance jakarta-oro-2.0.8.jar) identifies its version. Currently artifactId and groupId are same as I couldn't find something which could return me the Maven groupId of the dependency based on artifactId. Though this is not a perfect solution it provides a good ground to speed up Mavenisation.

  • It moves all source folders according to Maven convention (like src/main/java)

  • As Eclipse projects having names with spaces are difficult to deal on Linux/Unix environment, it renames them as well with names without spaces.

  • Resultant pom.xml files contain the dependencies and basic pom structure. You have to add required Maven plugins manually.

node.contents: Still true now ?

astNode.text: Still true now ?

node.contents: My question is, is there a wizard or automatic importer for converting an existing Eclipse Java project to a Maven project, using the Maven plugin?

astNode.text: My question is, is there a wizard or automatic importer for converting an existing Eclipse Java project to a Maven project, using the Maven plugin?

node.contents: As far as I know, there is nothing that will automagically convert an Eclipse project into a Maven project (i.e. modify the layout, create a POM, "generate" and feed it with metadata, detect libraries and their versions to add them to the POM, etc). Eclipse just doesn't have enough metadata to make this possible (this is precisely the point of the POM) and/or to produce a decent result.

astNode.text: As far as I know, there is nothing that will automagically convert an Eclipse project into a Maven project (i.e. modify the layout, create a POM, "generate" and feed it with metadata, detect libraries and their versions to add them to the POM, etc). Eclipse just doesn't have enough metadata to make this possible (this is precisely the point of the POM) and/or to produce a decent result.

node.contents: Or should I create a new Maven project and manually copy over all source files, libs, etc

astNode.text: Or should I create a new Maven project and manually copy over all source files, libs, etc

node.contents: That would be the best option in my opinion. Create a Maven project, copy/move sources, resources, tests, test resources into their respective directories, declare dependencies, etc.

astNode.text: That would be the best option in my opinion. Create a Maven project, copy/move sources, resources, tests, test resources into their respective directories, declare dependencies, etc.

node.contents: Yes, I was looking specifically at the m2eclipse plugin -- it's the one suggested on the Maven website, and looks like it's decently supported.

astNode.text: Yes, I was looking specifically at the m2eclipse plugin -- it's the one suggested on the Maven website, and looks like it's decently supported.

node.contents: yes, it does ;)

astNode.text: yes, it does ;)

node.contents: Although it enables M2Eclipse, it's not really a wizard not does it import an existing Eclipse project. Rather, it gives the user an option of selecting dependencies, etc., which may be difficult if the user doesn't have much experience with Maven.

astNode.text: Although it enables M2Eclipse, it's not really a wizard not does it import an existing Eclipse project. Rather, it gives the user an option of selecting dependencies, etc., which may be difficult if the user doesn't have much experience with Maven.

node.contents: I interpreted the question as 'do I need to create a new project and manually copy stuff around to use the m2eclipse plugin?', I'll clarify.

astNode.text: I interpreted the question as 'do I need to create a new project and manually copy stuff around to use the m2eclipse plugin?', I'll clarify.

node.contents: The maven menu item is not available for me from the right click menu (latest m2eclipse), chengdong's answer works.

astNode.text: The maven menu item is not available for me from the right click menu (latest m2eclipse), chengdong's answer works.

node.contents: On the current version of Eclipse (4.2) and m2eclipse the menu item is Convert / Convert to Maven Project.

astNode.text: On the current version of Eclipse (4.2) and m2eclipse the menu item is Convert / Convert to Maven Project.

node.contents: @Jesper menu item is "Configure / Convert to Maven Project"

astNode.text: @Jesper menu item is "Configure / Convert to Maven Project"

node.contents: If you just want to create a default POM and enable m2eclipse features: so I'm assuming you do not currently have an alternative automated build setup you're trying to import, and I'm assuming you're talking about the m2eclipse plugin.

astNode.text: If you just want to create a default POM and enable m2eclipse features: so I'm assuming you do not currently have an alternative automated build setup you're trying to import, and I'm assuming you're talking about the m2eclipse plugin.

node.contents: The m2eclipse plugin provides a right-click option on a project, submenu Maven, option Enable Dependency Management. That'll do the necessary to enable the plugin for that project.

astNode.text: The m2eclipse plugin provides a right-click option on a project, submenu Maven, option Enable Dependency Management. That'll do the necessary to enable the plugin for that project.

node.contents: To answer 'is there an automatic importer or wizard?': not that I know of. Using the option above will allow you to enable the m2eclipse plugin for your existing project avoiding the manual copying. You will still need to actually set up the dependencies and other stuff you need to build yourself.

astNode.text: To answer 'is there an automatic importer or wizard?': not that I know of. Using the option above will allow you to enable the m2eclipse plugin for your existing project avoiding the manual copying. You will still need to actually set up the dependencies and other stuff you need to build yourself.

node.contents: Will this create the maven folder structure ?

astNode.text: Will this create the maven folder structure ?

node.contents: @Mr_and_Mrs_D: No

astNode.text: @Mr_and_Mrs_D: No

node.contents: Right click on the Project name > Configure > Convert to Maven Project > click finish. Here you will add some dependencies to download and add your expected jar file.

astNode.text: Right click on the Project name > Configure > Convert to Maven Project > click finish. Here you will add some dependencies to download and add your expected jar file.

node.contents: This will create an auto-generated pom.xml file. Open that file in xml format in your eclipse editor. After build tag (</build>) add your dependencies which you can copy from maven website and add them there. Now you are good to go. These dependencies will automatically add your required jar files.

astNode.text: This will create an auto-generated pom.xml file. Open that file in xml format in your eclipse editor. After build tag (</build>) add your dependencies which you can copy from maven website and add them there. Now you are good to go. These dependencies will automatically add your required jar files.

node.contents: My solution (@ShriKant Vashishtha) mentioned below solves all problems described here. Creates Maven structure, removes spaces in folder names, creates pom.xml and moves source folders in Maven structure

astNode.text: My solution (@ShriKant Vashishtha) mentioned below solves all problems described here. Creates Maven structure, removes spaces in folder names, creates pom.xml and moves source folders in Maven structure

node.contents: Start from m2e 0.13.0 (if not earlier than), you can convert a Java project to maven project from the context menu. Here is how:

astNode.text: Start from m2e 0.13.0 (if not earlier than), you can convert a Java project to maven project from the context menu. Here is how:

node.contents:
• select the java project and popup the context menu
  • select Configure>Convert to Maven Project

astNode.text:
• select the java project and popup the context menu
  • select Configure>Convert to Maven Project

node.contents: Chengdong's answer is correct, you should use Configure>Convert to Maven Project. However, I must add the conversion process has been greatly improved since m2e 0.13.0 : m2e 1.1+ and m2e-wtp 0.16.0+ can now convert the existing eclipse settings into maven plugin configuration .

astNode.text: Chengdong's answer is correct, you should use Configure>Convert to Maven Project. However, I must add the conversion process has been greatly improved since m2e 0.13.0 : m2e 1.1+ and m2e-wtp 0.16.0+ can now convert the existing eclipse settings into maven plugin configuration .

node.contents: As for the dependency conversion matter, you can try the JBoss Tools (JBT) 4.0 Maven integration feature, which contains an experimental conversion wizard, plugged into m2e's conversion process : http://docs.jboss.org/tools/whatsnew/maven/maven-news-4.0.0.Beta1.html.

astNode.text: As for the dependency conversion matter, you can try the JBoss Tools (JBT) 4.0 Maven integration feature, which contains an experimental conversion wizard, plugged into m2e's conversion process : http://docs.jboss.org/tools/whatsnew/maven/maven-news-4.0.0.Beta1.html.

node.contents: It does not pretend to be the ultimate solution (nothing can), be it should greatly help bootstrap your Maven conversion process.

astNode.text: It does not pretend to be the ultimate solution (nothing can), be it should greatly help bootstrap your Maven conversion process.

node.contents: Also, FYI, here are some ideas to enhance m2e's conversion process, refactoring to use a Maven layout will most probably be implemented in the future.

astNode.text: Also, FYI, here are some ideas to enhance m2e's conversion process, refactoring to use a Maven layout will most probably be implemented in the future.

node.contents: JBT 4.0 (requires Eclipse JavaEE Juno) can be installed from http://download.jboss.org/jbosstools/updates/stable/juno/ or from the Eclipse Marketplace

astNode.text: JBT 4.0 (requires Eclipse JavaEE Juno) can be installed from http://download.jboss.org/jbosstools/updates/stable/juno/ or from the Eclipse Marketplace
